title: Ticket #7331: Same executable forces same universe
description:
A single submit file is unable to queue the same executable to multiple universes. For example, the following results in 2 Local Universe jobs being submitted, 

the multiverse collapses
$ cat multiverse.sub
universe = local
executable = /usr/bin/env
output = multiverse.local.out
error = multiverse.local.err
accounting_group = cit.test
queue 1

universe = vanilla
output = multiverse.vanilla.out
error = multiverse.vanilla.err
queue 1

However, adding "executable = /bin/env" after "universe = vanilla" works as expected. Note, adding "executable = /usr/bin/env" still results in both jobs running in local.
remarks:
2019-Oct-22 10:34:31 by pfc:
This should be better documented at the very least, or prohibited by condor_submit if it's always a bad idea.

2019-Oct-23 11:26:37 by johnkn:
Yes, we should add an explicit check and error-out into condor_submit for this, the universe is the first thing that condor_submit looks at when interpreting the submit file and that can change the way it looks at all of the other submit keywords.

Because of standard universe, when the executable changes, condor_submit essentially does a reset of it's internal parsing state because the schedd requires that an executable be unique to a cluster id. Standard universe is going away in 8.9, so this hack will also (probably) go away.
